case_vignette: A healthy 45-year-old woman presents with a several-month history of a small papule at the corner of her right eye. The lesion is asymptomatic and is not enlarging, but she has cosmetic concerns. She denies diplopia, vision loss, or any other lesions on her face and body. Examination reveals a dome-shaped, smooth, translucent papule filled with watery fluid located below the lateral canthus of her right eye.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a small bump at the corner of my right eye that has been there for several months.
Has the size or appearance of the bump changed over time?
No, the bump is not enlarging and its appearance has remained the same.
Is the bump painful or do you feel any irritation in that area?
The bump is asymptomatic, so I don't feel any pain or irritation.
Have you had similar bumps in the past or do you have a history of skin conditions?
No, I don't have any other lesions on my face and body, nor a history of similar bumps or skin conditions.
Do you have any family history of skin cancers or benign skin tumors?
I haven't mentioned any family history related to skin cancers or benign skin tumors.
Does the bump have a smooth, fleshy appearance and is it located near the tear duct?
Yes, the bump is smooth and translucent, and it is located below the lateral canthus of my right eye, not near the tear duct.
Final Diagnosis: Chalazion.

The patient confirms that there are no other lesions on their face or body, and there is no personal or family history of similar bumps or skin conditions. The patient describes the bump as smooth and translucent, situated below the lateral canthus of the right eye, away from the tear duct.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The final diagnosis is likely a cyst, specifically a conjunctival cyst.
